channel.title: Music Mixing on Pandaqi Tutorials
channel.description: Recent content in Music Mixing on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: This is a course about mixing. That means you should already have your arrangement ( = a song written down fully) and your recordings of that arrangement.

item.title: The Disconnect I
item.description: I also wrote a great chapter about this topic for my recording course: The Disconnect. That one focuses more on details and examples related to recording.

item.title: The Disconnect II: Sound Waves
item.description: I want to give some basic terminology and understanding about what audio waves actually are. These terms are very common in the field, so it’s good to know them.

item.title: The 3D space
item.description: To me, mixing is about two “holy trinities”. Everything else is not that important. And if it is, you’ll learn those details only from experience and mixing a lot.

item.title: Tools
item.description: As stated, this course is only about mixing. So you should already have your audio, which means I won’t talk about microphones, cables, or anything of the sort.

item.title: How to use a DAW
item.description: Alright, you’ve installed your software (DAW). You understand the general purpose of music mixing, what makes it hard and what to do about that.

item.title: Starting a project
item.description: Previous chapter gave you all the tools for working with a DAW! This chapter can, therefore, be quite simple.

item.title: Monitoring
item.description: The verb monitoring simply means “observing” or “checking”. In our case, it means that you hear the sound you’re producing.

item.title: Controls: Overview
item.description: You have a DAW and know how to use it. You have your new project open. You have some way to monitor what you’re doing, a workflow for listening and improving.

item.title: Timing
item.description: This one might seem obvious. Place audio files where they should start, right? Well, if you have audio files that all use the same rhythm perfectly, it is simple to get timing right.

item.title: Volume
item.description: Volume is often called “gain”. I, and many others, might use the terms interchangeably. But their meaning remains the same: how loud a track will be played.

item.title: Panning
item.description: Panning is the control that makes the difference between Mono and Stereo sound. By default, every track is panned to center (C).

item.title: Automation
item.description: Automation. The magical sauce that nobody wants to use when they just start out. The practical tip that everybody ignores until they realize it’s the truth.

item.title: Effects: Overview
item.description: You’re ready for the second holy trinity of mixing: Effects. This is, again, a short chapter to take a breather and indicate we’re moving to a new section.

item.title: Compression
item.description: Every recording has a certain dynamic range. That’s the range between the lowest volume and the highest volume. Changes in volume are, therefore, also often called dynamics.

item.title: Equalizer (EQ)
item.description: In a way, last chapter (about compression) was about the equalizer of volume. The compressor reduces the range from the lowest to highest volume, making the recording a little more equal in terms of power.

item.title: Reverb & Delay
item.description: Delay and Reverb are related effects. But they’re certainly not the same or interchangeable. After many failed attempts at using it, I finally learned the one true lesson!

item.title: Vocals
item.description: Numerous times, I’ve mentioned that vocals are the most important element in a mix (that has lyrics). It’s the loudest one.

item.title: Distortion
item.description: We’re nearing the end of this course. This chapter wasn’t included, at first. But as I went through all my old projects to find clips for my examples, I realized this principle was too important to leave out.

item.title: Mastering
item.description: Some people call “mastering” an entirely different skill than “mixing”. I think that’s extreme. To me, it’s just one part of the mixing toolset.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: Congratulations! You’ve reached the end of the course on mixing! I’ve taught and shown you every single useful idea and practical tip I could think of.
